{{Year box}} '''1873 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[American football]]== '''College championship''' * [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|College football national championship]] – [[Princeton Tigers football|Princeton Tigers]] '''Events''' * 19 October — representatives of [[Yale Bulldogs football|Yale Bulldogs]], [[Columbia Lions football|Columbia Lions]], [[Princeton Tigers football|Princeton Tigers]] and [[Rutgers Scarlet Knights football|Rutgers Scarlet Knights]] meet at the Fifth Avenue Hotel in New York City to codify the first set of intercollegiate football rules.
==[[Association football]]== '''England''' * [[1873 FA Cup Final|FA Cup final]] – [[Wanderers F.C.|The Wanderers]] 2–0 [[Oxford University A.F.C.|Oxford University]] at [[Lillie Bridge]] in London '''Scotland''' * 13 March — formation of the [[Scottish Football Association]] (SFA). [[Queen's Park FC|Queen's Park]] and [[Third Lanark F.C.|Third Lanark]] are among the original members. * The Scottish Football Association Challenge Cup, commonly known as the [[Scottish Cup]], is launched by the [[Scottish Football Association]] as a knockout cup competition ahead of the 1873–74 season.
==[[Australian rules football]]== '''Events''' * [[St Kilda Football Club]] established.
==[[Baseball]]== '''National championship''' * [[National Association of Professional Base Ball Players]] champion – [[History of the Boston Braves|Boston Red Stockings]] (second consecutive season)
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 23 September — [[Tom Allen (boxer)|Tom Allen]] becomes the undisputed Heavyweight Champion of America when he defeats [[Mike McCoole]] in the 7th round at "Chateau Island" near St. Louis, Missouri.<ref name="TA">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/allen-t.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Tom Allen]. Retrieved on 12 November 2009.</ref> * 29 October — McCoole is arrested and later convicted for shooting another pugilist called Patsy Mavery at St. Louis. This ends his career.<ref name="MM">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/mccoole.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Mike McCoole]. Retrieved on 12 November 2009.</ref> * 18 November — Allen defends his title against [[Ben Hogan (boxer)|Ben Hogan]] at Pacific City, Iowa. In the third round, Hogan claims a foul but is refused by the referee. A riot erupts and the bout is forced to end, being declared a draw. Allen retains the American Championship but does not fight again until 1876.<ref name="TA"/>
==[[Canadian football]]== '''Events''' * [[Toronto Argonauts]] founded by the Argonaut Rowing Club
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * Player qualification rules are introduced with players having to decide at the start of a season whether they will play for their county of birth or their county of residence. Until now, it has been quite common for a player to play for two counties during the course of a single season. Increasing media interest in county cricket enables a semi-official championship to be inaugurated, based on media consensus. '''England''' * [[Champion County]]<ref>A semi-official seasonal title proclaimed by media consensus prior to December 1889 when the official County Championship is constituted.</ref> – [[Gloucestershire County Cricket Club|Gloucestershire]] shares the title with [[Nottinghamshire County Cricket Club|Nottinghamshire]] * Most runs – [[W. G. Grace]] 1805 @ 72.20 (HS 192*) * Most wickets – [[James Southerton]] 148 @ 13.96 (BB 8–113)
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1873 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Tom Kidd (golfer)|Tom Kidd]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''Events''' * Inaugural running of the [[Preakness Stakes]] is won by [[Survivor (horse)|Survivor]] '''England''' * [[1873 Grand National|Grand National]] – Disturbance * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Cecilia * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Gang Forward]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Doncaster (horse)|Doncaster]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – Marie Stuart * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – Marie Stuart '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Don Juan '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Mignonette '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – Torrent * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Kyrle Daly '''USA''' * [[Preakness Stakes]] – [[Survivor (horse)|Survivor]] * [[Belmont Stakes]] – [[Springbok (horse)|Springbok]]
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 29 March — [[Cambridge University Boat Club|Cambridge]] wins the 30th [[The Boat Race 1873|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
==[[Rugby football]]== '''Events''' * 3 March — formation of the [[Scottish Rugby Football Union]] in a meeting held at [[Glasgow Academy]], Elmbank Street, [[Glasgow]]. Eight clubs are represented at the foundation: [[Glasgow Academicals RFC|Glasgow Academicals]]; [[Edinburgh Academical Football Club]]; [[West of Scotland F.C.]]; [[University of St Andrews Rugby Football Club]]; [[Royal High School (Edinburgh)#Sports and games|Royal High School FP]]; [[Merchiston Castle School|Merchistonians]]; [[Edinburgh University RFC|Edinburgh University]] and [[Glasgow University Rugby Football Club|Glasgow University]]. * [[Gloucester Rugby|Gloucester RFC]], [[Halifax R.L.F.C.|Halifax]], [[Hawick RFC]], [[Salford Red Devils|Salford RLFC]], [[St Helens R.F.C.]], [[Wakefield Trinity|Wakefield Trinity RLFC]] and [[Widnes Vikings|Widnes RLFC]] all established in 1873.

{{Year box}} '''1896 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[American football]]== '''College championship''' * [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|College football national championship]] – [[Princeton Tigers]]
'''Professional championships''' * [[Western Pennsylvania Professional Football Circuit|Western Pennsylvania champions]] – [[Allegheny Athletic Association]]
==[[Association football]]== '''England''' * [[The Football League]] – [[Aston Villa]] 45 points, [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] 41, [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] 39, [[Bolton Wanderers]] 37, [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] 37, [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke FC]] 30 * [[1896 FA Cup Final|FA Cup final]] – [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|The Wednesday]] 2–1 [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] at [[Crystal Palace National Sports Centre|Crystal Palace]], London. '''Scotland''' * [[Scottish Football League]] – [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] * [[1896 Scottish Cup Final|Scottish Cup final]] – [[Heart of Midlothian F.C.|Hearts]] 3–1 [[Hibernian F.C.|Hibernian]] at Logie Green
==[[Baseball]]== '''National championship''' * [[Baltimore Orioles (19th century)|Baltimore Orioles]] win the third of three successive [[National League]] championships '''Events''' * [[Temple Cup]] – [[Baltimore Orioles (19th century)|Baltimore Orioles]] 4–0 [[Cleveland Spiders]]
==[[Boxing]]== '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>{{cite web|title=Cyber Boxing Zone |url=http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm |work= |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hg1si20f?url=http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm |archivedate=2009-06-20 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-06-20 |df= }}</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[James J. Corbett]] * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – title vacant * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – [[Tommy Ryan]] * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – vacant → [[Kid Lavigne|George "Kid" Lavigne]] * [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship – [[George Dixon (boxer)|George Dixon]] * [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship – [[Jimmy Barry]]
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * [[England national cricket team|England]] retain [[The Ashes]], defeating [[Australia national cricket team|Australia]] 2–1 in a three-match series. In a low-scoring decider at [[The Oval]], England win by 66 runs. '''England''' * [[County Championship]] – [[Yorkshire CCC|Yorkshire]] * [[Minor Counties Championship]] – [[Worcestershire CCC|Worcestershire]] * Most runs – [[K S Ranjitsinhji]] 2780 @ 57.91 (HS 171*) * Most wickets – [[J T Hearne]] 257 @ 14.28 (BB 9–73) * [[Wisden Cricketers of the Year|Wisden Five Cricketers of the Season]] – [[Syd Gregory]], [[Dick Lilley]], [[K S Ranjitsinhji]], [[Tom Richardson (cricketer)|Tom Richardson]], [[Hugh Trumble]] '''Australia''' * [[Sheffield Shield]] – [[New South Wales cricket team|New South Wales]] * Most runs – [[Harry Donnan]] 626 @ 69.55 (HS 160) * Most wickets – [[Tom McKibbin]] 46 @ 23.86 (BB 8–93) '''India''' * [[Bombay Quadrangular|Bombay Presidency]] – [[Europeans cricket team|Europeans]] shared with [[Parsees cricket team|Parsees]] '''South Africa''' * [[SuperSport Series|Currie Cup]] – not contested '''West Indies''' * [[Inter-Colonial Tournament]] – not contested
==[[Figure skating]]== '''Events''' * Inaugural [[1896 World Figure Skating Championships|World Figure Skating Championships]] (open to men only) is held in [[Saint Petersburg]] '''World Figure Skating Championships''' * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Men's Champion]] – [[Gilbert Fuchs]] (Germany)
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1896 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Harry Vardon]] (the first of Vardon's six British Open titles) * [[1896 U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]] – [[James Foulis]] '''Other tournaments''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – [[Freddie Tait]] * [[United States Amateur Championship (men's golf)|US Amateur]] – [[H. J. Whigham]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1896 Grand National|Grand National]] – The Soarer * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Thais (horse)|Thais]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[St. Frusquin]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Persimmon (horse)|Persimmon]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – [[Canterbury Pilgrim]] * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – Persimmon '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Newhaven '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Millbrook '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – Royston Crow * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Gulsalberk '''USA''' * [[1896 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – Lieut. Gibson * [[Preakness Stakes]] – Margrave * [[Belmont Stakes]] – Hastings
==[[Ice hockey]]==
* 14 February — the Winnipeg Victorias defeat the Montreal Victorias 2–0 in a challenge match to win the [[1896 Stanley Cup championship]] * 7 March — the Montreal Victorias are the [[1896 AHAC season]] champions. * March — [[Queen's Golden Gaels|Queen's University]] defeats [[Stratford, Ontario]] 12–3 to win the [[Ontario Hockey Association]] (OHA) title. The club does not challenge Winnipeg. * 17 November — the [[Western Pennsylvania Hockey League]], which later became the first ice hockey league to openly trade and hire players, began play at [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania|Pittsburgh's]] [[Schenley Park Casino]]. * 17 December — the Schenley Park Casino, which was the first multi-purpose [[arena]] with the technology to create an artificial ice surface in North America as well as the home to the Western Pennsylvania Hockey League, was destroyed in a fire. * 30 December — the Montreal Victorias defeat the Winnipeg Victorias 6–5 in a challenge match to regain the [[Stanley Cup]]
==[[Motor racing]]== '''Paris-Marseille-Paris Trail''' * The [[1896 Paris–Marseille–Paris]] Trail is held over 1710 km from 24 September to 3 October and won by [[Émile Mayade]] driving a [[Panhard-Levassor]] 8 hp model in a time of 67:42:58. The race is in retrospect sometimes referred to as the ''II Grand Prix de l'ACF''.<ref>[http://www.teamdan.com/archive/gen/upto1903/1896.html 1896 Grand Prix and Paris Races]. Retrieved on 7 September 2009.</ref>
==[[Olympic Games]]== '''1896 Summer Olympics''' * The [[1896 Summer Olympics]], the first modern Games, takes place in Athens with 13 nations competing, the most competitors coming from Greece, Germany and France. * 16 April — American [[James Connolly (athlete born 1868)|James Connolly]] wins the [[triple jump]] to become the first [[Olympic Games|Olympic]] champion in over 1,500 years. * Winners receive a [[silver]] medal and a crown of [[olive]] branches; Greece wins the most medals (46) and the United States wins the most gold medals (11).
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 28 March — [[Oxford University Boat Club|Oxford]] wins the 53rd [[The Boat Race 1896|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]] * There is no [[Harvard–Yale Regatta]] during "a breakdown in relations between the two schools".<ref name=150yrs>[http://www.gocrimson.com/sports/mcrew-hw/tradition/harvard-yale-regatta "Harvard–Yale Regatta – 150 Years of Tradition"]. Harvard Men's Heavyweight Crew. Retrieved 2013-05-10.</ref> From the third Race in 1859, the only exceptions outside major wars are 1871 and 1896.
==[[Rugby league]]== '''Events''' * In the [[1895–96 Northern Rugby Football Union season]]'s final match, [[Manningham F.C.|Manningham]] defeats [[Halifax R.L.F.C.|Halifax]] to claim the inaugural [[Rugby Football League Championship]]. * The inaugural Rugby League [[Challenge Cup]] competition begins in the 1896–97 season.
'''England''' * [[Rugby Football League Championship|Championship]] – [[Manningham F.C.|Manningham]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Lancashire League Championship]] – [[List of defunct rugby league clubs|Runcorn]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Yorkshire League Championship]] – [[Manningham F.C.|Manningham]]
==[[Rugby union]]== '''Home Nations Championship''' * 14th [[Six Nations Championship|Home Nations Championship]] series is won by [[Ireland national rugby union team|Ireland]]
==[[Skiing]]== * The foundation of the Ski-Club of [[Grenoble]] by [[Henry Duhamel]].
==[[Speed skating]]== '''Speed Skating World Championships''' * [[1896 World Allround Speed Skating Championships|Men's All-round Champion]] – [[Jaap Eden]] (Netherlands)
==[[Tennis]]== '''England''' * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Harold Mahony]] (Ireland) defeats [[Wilfred Baddeley]] (GB) 6–2 6–8 5–7 8–6 6–3 * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Charlotte Cooper (tennis)|Charlotte Cooper Sterry]] (GB) defeats [[Alice Simpson-Pickering]] (GB) 6–2 6–3 '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – [[André Vacherot]] defeats [[Gérard Brosselin]] 6–1 7–5 '''USA''' * [[US Open (tennis)|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Robert Wrenn]] defeats [[Fred Hovey]] 7–5 3–6 6–0 1–6 6–1 * [[US Open (tennis)|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Elisabeth Moore]] defeats [[Juliette Atkinson]] 6–4 4–6 6–2 6–2

{{Year box}} '''1917 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
Note — ''many sporting events did not take place because of [[World War I]]''
==[[American football]]== '''College championship''' * [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|College football national championship]] – [[Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football|Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets]] (coached by [[John Heisman]]) *[[Camp Randall Stadium]], home of the [[Wisconsin Badgers football|Wisconsin Badgers]], opens
==[[Association football]]== '''Europe''' * There is no major football in Europe due to [[World War I]] '''Norway''' * Foundation of [[Rosenborg BK]] at [[Trondheim]]
==[[Track and field athletics|Athletics]]== '''Men's 1500 metres''' * [[John Zander]] (Sweden) breaks the world record by running a time of 2:19.1
==[[Australian rules football]]== '''VFL Premiership''': * [[Collingwood Football Club|Collingwood]] wins the 21st [[Australian Football League|VFL]] Premiership: Collingwood 9.20 (74) d [[Fitzroy Football Club|Fitzroy]] 5.9 (39) at [[Melbourne Cricket Ground]] (MCG) '''[[South Australian National Football League|South Australian Football League]]''': * not contested due to World War I '''[[West Australian Football League]]''': * 15 September: [[South Fremantle Football Club|South Fremantle]] 6.5 (41) defeats [[East Fremantle Football Club|East Fremantle]] 3.8 (26) for their second consecutive WAFL premiership.
==[[Bandy]]== '''Sweden''' * [[Allsvenskan and Elitserien (bandy)|Championship final]] – [[IFK Uppsala Bandy|IFK Uppsala]] 11–2 [[AIK]]
==[[Baseball]]== '''World Series''' * 6–15 October — [[1917 Chicago White Sox season|Chicago White Sox]] (AL) defeats [[1917 New York Giants season|New York Giants]] (NL) to win the [[1917 World Series]] by 4 games to 2.
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * [[Ted "Kid" Lewis]] regains the [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship and holds it until 1919. * [[Al McCoy (boxer)|Al McCoy]] loses the [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship title to [[Mike O'Dowd]], who knocks him out in the 6th round at [[Brooklyn]] * [[Benny Leonard]], widely regarded as the greatest-ever lightweight, defeats [[Freddie Welsh]] at [[New York City|New York]] to win the [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship, which he holds until he retires in 1925 * Another great champion, [[Pete Herman]] defeats [[Kid Williams]] over 20 rounds at [[New Orleans]] to take the [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship, which he holds until 1920 '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm Cyber Boxing Zone]</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Jess Willard]] * [[World Light Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Battling Levinsky]] * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – [[Al McCoy (boxer)|Al McCoy]] → [[Mike O'Dowd]] * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – [[Jack Britton]] → [[Ted "Kid" Lewis]] * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – [[Freddie Welsh]] → [[Benny Leonard]] * [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship – [[Johnny Kilbane]] * [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship – [[Kid Williams]] → [[Pete Herman]] * [[World Flyweight Champion]]ship – [[Jimmy Wilde]]
==[[Canadian football]]== '''Grey Cup''' * not contested due to [[World War I]]
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * There is no [[first-class cricket]] in England, Australia, New Zealand, South Africa or the West Indies due to [[World War I]] '''India''' * [[Bombay Quadrangular]] – [[Europeans cricket team|Europeans]] shared with [[Parsees cricket team|Parsees]]
==[[Cycling]]== '''[[List of Tour de France winners|Tour de France]]''' * not contested due to [[World War I]] '''[[List of Giro d'Italia general classification winners|Giro d'Italia]]''' * not contested due to [[World War I]]
==[[Figure skating]]== '''World Figure Skating Championships''' * not contested due to [[World War I]]
==[[Golf]]== '''Events''' * All major championships are cancelled due to [[World War I]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1917 Grand National|Grand National]] – ''not held due to [[World War I]]'' * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Diadem (horse)|Diadem]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Gay Crusader]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – Gay Crusader * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – [[Sunny Jane (horse)|Sunny Jane]] * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – Gay Crusader '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Westcourt '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Belle Mahone '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – Pay Only * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – First Flier '''USA''' * [[1917 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – Omar Khayyam * [[Preakness Stakes]] – Kalitan * [[Belmont Stakes]] – Hourless
==[[Ice hockey]]== '''Stanley Cup''' * 17–26 March — [[Seattle Metropolitans]] (PCHA) defeats [[1916–17 Montreal Canadiens season|Montreal Canadiens]] (NHA) in the [[1917 Stanley Cup Finals]] by 3 games to 1 '''Events''' * [[1917 Allan Cup|Allan Cup]] – Toronto Dentals * 10 November — after Eddie Livingstone, owner of the Toronto NHA team, refuses to sell, the NHA votes to suspend operations * 26 November — in a secret meeting, several owners of the NHA form the [[National Hockey League]] (NHL) to force out the owner of the [[Toronto Blueshirts]] NHA team. Toronto’s [[Arena Gardens]] will operate a temporary franchise in Toronto while [[Quebec Bulldogs]] becomes a NHL member but is suspended for the inaugural season. * 19 December — the opening NHL games are played to begin the new league’s [[1917–18 NHL season|inaugural season]]
==[[Motor racing]]== '''Events''' * No major races are held anywhere worldwide due to [[World War I]]
==[[Multi-sport event]]s== '''Far Eastern Championship Games''' * Third [[Far Eastern Championship Games]] held in [[Tokyo]], [[Empire of Japan]]
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * [[The Boat Race|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]] – not contested due to [[World War I]] * International Eight Boat Race - England v Australia. Rowed Putney To Hammersmith, London, 20th Oct. 1917. Won By Australia by 3/4 length.
==[[Rugby league]]== '''England''' * All first-class competitions are cancelled due to [[World War I]] '''Australia''' * [[New South Wales Rugby League premiership|NSW Premiership]] – [[Balmain Tigers|Balmain]] (outright winner) '''New Zealand''' *[[1917 New Zealand rugby league season]]
==[[Rugby union]]== '''Five Nations Championship''' * [[Six Nations Championship|Five Nations Championship]] series is not contested due to [[World War I]]
==[[Speed skating]]== '''Speed Skating World Championships''' * not contested due to [[World War I]]
==[[Tennis]]== '''Australia''' * [[List of Australian Open Men's Singles champions|Australian Men's Singles Championship]] – not contested due to [[World War I]] '''England''' * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – not contested due to [[World War I]] * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – not contested due to [[World War I]] '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – not contested due to [[World War I]] * [[List of French Open Women's Singles champions|French Women's Singles Championship]] – not contested due to [[World War I]] '''USA''' * [[US Open (tennis)|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Lindley Murray (tennis)|Lindley Murray]] (USA) defeats [[Nathaniel Niles (tennis)|Nathaniel Niles]] (USA) 5–7 8–6 6–3 6–3 * [[US Open (tennis)|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Molla Bjurstedt Mallory]] (Norway) defeats [[Marion Vanderhoef Morse]] (USA) 4–6 6–0 6–2 '''Davis Cup''' * 1917 International Lawn Tennis Challenge – ''not contested''

{{Year box}} '''1920 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport. {{TOC right}}
==[[American football]]== * [[NFL championship]] – [[1920 Akron Pros season|Akron Pros]] * [[Rose Bowl Game|Rose Bowl]] (1919 season): ** The [[Harvard Crimson]] won 7-6 over the [[Oregon Ducks|Oregon Webfoots]] to win the college football national championship * 17 September — the [[National Football League]] (NFL) is founded as the American Professional Football Association in [[Canton, Ohio]]. Of the teams in the current NFL, only the Decatur Staleys (renamed the [[Chicago Bears]]) and the Racine (Chicago) Cardinals (the current [[Arizona Cardinals]]) remain in existence. * 14 December — Notre Dame player [[George Gipp]] (1895–1920), mainly remembered for his deathbed quote to coach [[Knute Rockne]]: "Win just one for the Gipper".
==[[Association football]]== '''England''' * [[The Football League]] – [[West Bromwich Albion]] 60 points, [[Burnley FC|Burnley]] 51, [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] 49, [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] 48, [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] 48, [[Bolton Wanderers]] 47 * [[1920 FA Cup Final|FA Cup final]] – [[Aston Villa]] 1–0 [[Huddersfield Town]] (after extra time) at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]], London * The Football League is expanded by the formation of the original [[Football League Third Division|Third Division]]. New clubs admitted to the league include [[Leeds United]] and [[Cardiff City]], who are both elected to the [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]]. New members in the Third Division are: [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]], [[Brighton & Hove Albion]], [[Bristol Rovers]], [[Crystal Palace FC|Crystal Palace]], [[Exeter City]], [[Gillingham F.C.|Gillingham]], [[Luton Town]], [[Merthyr Town]] (1920 – 1930), [[Millwall FC|Millwall]], [[Newport County A.F.C.|Newport County]] (1920 – 1988), [[Northampton Town]], [[Norwich City]], [[Plymouth Argyle]], [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]], [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] (QPR), [[Reading F.C.|Reading]], [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]], [[Southend United]], [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea Town]], [[Swindon Town]] and [[Watford F.C.|Watford]]. '''Germany''' * [[List of German football champions|National Championship]] – [[1. FC Nürnberg]] 2–0 [[SpVgg Fürth]] at Frankfurt
==[[Track and field athletics|Athletics]]== '''Men's 100 metres''' * [[Jackson Scholz]] (USA) equals the world record of 10.6 seconds.
==[[Australian rules football]]== '''[[1920 VFL season|VFL Premiership]]''' * 2 October – [[Richmond Football Club|Richmond]] wins the 24th [[Australian Football League|VFL]] Premiership, defeating [[Collingwood Football Club|Collingwood]] 7.10 (52) to 5.5 (35) [[1920 VFL Grand Final|in the Grand Final]] '''[[South Australian National Football League|South Australian Football League]]''' * 18 September – [[North Adelaide Football Club|North Adelaide]] defeat [[Norwood Football Club|Norwood]] 10.9 (69) to 3.3 (21) to win its fourth SAFL premiership. '''[[West Australian Football League]]''' * 25 September – [[East Perth Football Club|East Perth]] defeats [[East Fremantle Football Club|East Fremantle]] 6.16 (52) to 4.6 (30) to win its second consecutive premiership.
==[[Bandy]]== '''Sweden''' * [[Allsvenskan and Elitserien (bandy)|Championship final]] – [[IFK Uppsala Bandy|IFK Uppsala]] 3–2 [[IF Linnéa]]
==[[Baseball]]== '''World Series''' * 5–12 October — [[1920 Cleveland Indians season|Cleveland Indians]] (AL) defeats [[1920 Brooklyn Dodgers season|Brooklyn Dodgers]] (NL) by 5 games to 2 to win the [[1920 World Series]] '''Major League Baseball''' * The [[Boston Red Sox#Sale of Babe Ruth|sale of Babe Ruth]]. [[1920 Boston Red Sox season|Boston Red Sox]] transfers [[Babe Ruth]] to [[1920 New York Yankees season|New York Yankees]] for $125,000 and a $350,000 loan. Ruth hits 54 [[home run]]s for the Yankees in 1920, nearly double the record of 29 he hit [[1919 Major League Baseball season|in the 1919 season]]. * 16 August — [[Ray Chapman]] of [[1920 Cleveland Indians season|Cleveland Indians]] is hit on the head by a [[fastball]] from [[Carl Mays]] of [[1920 New York Yankees season|New York Yankees]]. He dies early next day, the second fatality of major league play. * [[1920 Chicago White Sox season|Chicago White Sox]] stars [[Eddie Cicotte]] and [[Shoeless Joe Jackson]] confess their roles in the [[Black Sox scandal]] '''Negro League Baseball''' * 13 February — the [[Negro National League (the first)|Negro National League]] is formed * 2 May — the first game of the new league is played at Indianapolis with the [[Indianapolis ABCs]] defeating the [[Chicago Giants]] (not to be confused with the [[Chicago American Giants]]) * [[Chicago American Giants]] wins the inaugural Negro National League pennant
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 6 May – [[Johnny Wilson (boxer)|Johnny Wilson]] wins the [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship by defeating [[Mike O'Dowd]] in 12 rounds at [[Boston]]. * 12 October – [[Georges Carpentier]] wins the [[World Light Heavyweight Champion]]ship after he knocks out [[Battling Levinsky]] in the 4th round at [[Jersey City]], his victory setting up the first "million dollar gate" when he fights [[Jack Dempsey]] in 1921. * 22 December – [[Joe Lynch (boxer)|Joe Lynch]] defeats [[Pete Herman]] in 15 rounds at New York to win the [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship. '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm Cyber Boxing Zone]</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Jack Dempsey]] * [[World Light Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Battling Levinsky]] → [[Georges Carpentier]] * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – [[Mike O'Dowd]] → [[Johnny Wilson (boxer)|Johnny Wilson]] * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – [[Jack Britton]] * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – [[Benny Leonard]] * [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship – [[Johnny Kilbane]] * [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship – [[Pete Herman]] → [[Joe Lynch (boxer)|Joe Lynch]] * [[World Flyweight Champion]]ship – [[Jimmy Wilde]]
==[[Canadian football]]== '''Grey Cup''' * [[8th Grey Cup]] – [[University of Toronto Varsity Blues]] 16–3 [[Toronto Argonauts]]
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * Post-war recovery continues and an [[English cricket team in Australia in 1920–21|English team]] goes to Australia in November to commence the first [[Test cricket|Test series]] since the war. * [[Derbyshire County Cricket Club|Derbyshire]] suffer the ignominy of a [[imperfect season|perfectly bad season]], losing all seventeen county matches with any play. This is the second and last time this has occurred in county cricket, and the only time in the official [[County Championship]]. '''England''' * [[County Championship]] – [[Middlesex CCC|Middlesex]] * [[Minor Counties Championship]] – [[Staffordshire CCC|Staffordshire]] * Most runs – [[Jack Hobbs]] 2827 @ 58.89 (HS 215) * Most wickets – [[Frank Woolley]] 185 @ 14.23 (BB 7–59) * [[Wisden Cricketers of the Year|Wisden Cricketer of the Year]] – [[Plum Warner]] '''Australia''' * [[Sheffield Shield]] – [[New South Wales cricket team|New South Wales]] * Most runs – [[Roy Park (sportsman)|Roy Park]] 648 @ 72.00 (HS 228) * Most wickets – [[Stork Hendry]] 29 @ 18.13 (BB 7–34) '''India''' * [[Bombay Quadrangular]] – [[Hindus cricket team|Hindus]] '''New Zealand''' * [[Plunket Shield]] – [[Auckland cricket team|Auckland]] '''South Africa''' * [[SuperSport Series|Currie Cup]] – ''not contested'' '''West Indies''' * [[Inter-Colonial Tournament]] – ''not contested''
==[[Cycling]]== '''Tour de France''' * [[Philippe Thys]] (Belgium) wins the 14th [[1920 Tour de France|Tour de France]] '''Giro d'Italia''' * [[Gaetano Belloni]] of [[Bianchi cycling team|Bianchi]] wins the eighth [[1920 Giro d'Italia|Giro d'Italia]]
==[[Field hockey]]== '''Olympic Games (Men's Competition)''' * Gold Medal – Great Britain * Silver Medal – Denmark * Bronze Medal – Belgium
==[[Figure skating]]== '''World Figure Skating Championships''' * The championships are not contested '''1920 Summer Olympics''' * Men's individual – [[Gillis Grafström]] (Sweden) * Women's individual – [[Magda Mauroy-Julin]] (Sweden) * Pairs – [[Ludowika Jakobsson]] and [[Walter Jakobsson]] (Finland)
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1920 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[George Duncan (golfer)|George Duncan]] * [[1920 U.S. Open (golf)|US Open]] – [[Ted Ray (golfer)|Ted Ray]] * [[1920 PGA Championship|USPGA Championship]] – [[Jock Hutchison]] '''Other tournaments''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – [[Cyril Tolley]] * [[United States Amateur Championship (men's golf)|US Amateur]] – [[Chick Evans]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''Events''' * The inaugural [[Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe]] is won by [[Comrade (horse)|Comrade]] '''England''' * [[1920 Grand National|Grand National]] – [[Troytown (horse)|Troytown]] * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Cinna (horse)|Cinna]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Tetratema]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Spion Kop (horse)|Spion Kop]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – [[Charlebelle]] * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Caligula (horse)|Caligula]] '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Poitrel '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – St. Paul '''France''' * [[Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe]] – [[Comrade (horse)|Comrade]] '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – Halston * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – He Goes '''USA''' * [[1920 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – Paul Jones * [[Preakness Stakes]] – Man o' War * [[1920 Belmont Stakes|Belmont Stakes]] – Man o' War
==[[Ice hockey]]== '''Events''' * Ice hockey is held at the [[1920 Summer Olympics]] and is the second winter sport to feature at the Olympics — 4 years before the inaugural Winter Games is held '''1920 Summer Olympics''' * Gold Medal – Canada * Silver Medal – USA * Bronze Medal – Czechoslovakia '''Stanley Cup''' * 22 March – 1 April — [[Ottawa Senators (original)|Ottawa Senators]] (NHL) defeats [[Seattle Metropolitans]] (PCHA) in the [[1920 Stanley Cup Finals]] by three games to two '''Events''' * [[1920 Allan Cup|Allan Cup]] – [[Winnipeg Falcons]] * [[1920 Memorial Cup]] – [[Toronto Canoe Club Paddlers]] defeated [[Selkirk Fishermen]] by two game total of 15-5 * 22 December — [[Hamilton Tigers (ice hockey)|Hamilton Tigers]], the reconstituted [[Quebec Bulldogs]] franchise, wins its first-ever NHL game in Hamilton, defeating [[Montreal Canadiens]] 5–0
==[[Motorsport]]== {{main|1920 in motorsport|List of 1920 motorsport champions}}
==[[Olympic Games]]== '''1920 Summer Olympics''' * The [[1920 Summer Olympics]] takes place in [[Antwerp (city)|Antwerp]] * The 1916 Summer Olympics planned for [[Berlin]] having been cancelled due to [[World War I]], the 1920 Games are awarded to Antwerp to "honour the suffering of the Belgian people" * United States wins the most medals (95) and the most gold medals (41)
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 28 March — [[Cambridge University Boat Club|Cambridge]] wins the 72nd [[The Boat Race 1920|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]], contested for the first time since March 1914
==[[Rugby league]]== *The [[1920 Great Britain Lions tour]] of Australia and New Zealand takes place mid-year. {{other uses}} {{redirect|Sportsmen|other uses of the term|hunters|and|fishermen}} {{Globalize|date=December 2010}} [[File:Jim Thorpe, 1912 Summer Olympics.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Jim Thorpe]] at the [[1912 Summer Olympics]]]]
An '''athlete''' (also '''sportsman''' or '''sportswoman''') is a person who competes in one or more [[sport]]s that involve [[physical strength]], speed or [[endurance]]. The application of the term to those who participate in other activities, such as horse riding or driving, is somewhat controversial.
Athletes may be [[Professional sports|professional]]s or [[amateur sports|amateurs]].<ref>Collins English Dictionary, Millennium Ed. - 'athlete'</ref> Most professional athletes have particularly well-developed physiques obtained by extensive physical training and strict exercise accompanied by a strict dietary regimen.
==Overview== [[File:Armedforces crosscountry coppingerandballas.jpg|thumb|left|Athletes taking part in a race on a snowy park in the U.S.]] The word "athlete" is a [[romanization]] of the {{lang-el|άθλητὴς}}, ''athlētēs'', one who participates in a contest; from ἄθλος, ''áthlos'', or ἄθλον, ''áthlon'', a contest or feat. The primary definition of "sportsman" according to Webster's ''Third Unabridged Dictionary'' (1960) is, "a person who is active in sports: as (a): one who engages in the sports of the field and especially in hunting or fishing." Athletes involved in isotonic exercises have an increased mean left ventricular end-diastolic volume and are less likely to be depressed.<ref>MORGANROTH, JOEL, et al. "[http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.1024.7587&rep=rep1&type=pdf Comparative left ventricular dimensions in trained athletes]." Annals of internal medicine 82.4 (1975): 521-524.</ref><ref>Oler, Michael J., et al. "[http://europepmc.org/abstract/med/7987512 Depression, suicidal ideation, and substance use among adolescents. Are athletes at less risk?]." Archives of Family Medicine 3.9 (1994): 781-785.</ref> Due to their strenuous physical activities, athletes are far more likely than the general population to visit [[massage]] salons and pay for services from massotherapists and masseurs.<ref>Jönhagen, Sven, et al. "[http://www.taichiqigongreikicentre.com.au/resources/Sports%20Massage%20after%20Eccentric%20Exercise.pdf Sports massage after eccentric exercise]." The American Journal of Sports Medicine 32.6 (2004): 1499-1503.</ref> Athletes whose sport espouses endurance more than strength usually have a lower calorie intake than other athletes.<ref>Thompson, Paul D., et al. "[http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/002604958490249X The effects of caloric restriction or exercise cessation on the serum lipid and lipoprotein concentrations of endurance athletes]." Metabolism 33.10 (1984): 943-950.</ref>
== Titles == {{see also|Athlete of the Year}}
==="All-around athlete"=== An "'''all-around athlete'''" is a person who competes in multiple sports at a high level. Examples of people who played more than one sport professionally include [[Jim Thorpe]], [[Lionel Conacher]], [[Deion Sanders]], [[Danny Ainge]], [[Babe Zaharias]] and [[Erin Phillips]]. Others include [[Ricky Williams]], [[Bo Jackson]], and [[Damon Allen]], each of whom was drafted both by [[Major League Baseball]] and by professional [[gridiron football]] leagues such as the [[National Football League|NFL]] and the [[Canadian Football League|CFL]]. Another female example is [[Heather Moyse]], a multiple Winter Olympic gold medalist in [[Bobsleigh|bobsled]] and member of the [[World Rugby Hall of Fame]] who also represented Canada internationally in [[track cycling]] and competed at [[U Sports|university]] level in basketball and track and field. Japanese athletes such as [[Kazushi Sakuraba]], [[Kazuyuki Fujita]], [[Masakatsu Funaki]] and [[Naoya Ogawa]] have successfully performed in [[professional wrestling]] (which isn't a sport) and competed in [[mixed martial arts]].
==="World's Greatest Athlete"=== The title of "'''World's Greatest Athlete'''" traditionally belongs to the world's top competitor in the [[decathlon]] (males) and [[heptathlon]] (females) in [[track and field]]. The [[decathlon]] consists of 10 events: [[100 meters]], [[long jump]], [[shot put]], [[high jump]], [[400 meters]], [[110 m hurdles]], [[discus]], [[pole vault]], [[Javelin throw|javelin]], and [[1500 m]]. The [[heptathlon]] consists of seven events: the [[100 m hurdles]], [[high jump]], [[shot put]], [[200 meters]], [[long jump]], [[Javelin throw|javelin]], and [[800 meters]]. These competitions require an athlete to possess the whole spectrum of athletic ability in order to be successful including speed, strength, coordination, jumping ability, and endurance.
Although the title "World's Greatest '''Athlete'''" seems a natural fit for these two events, its traditional association with the decathlon/heptathlon officially began with [[Jim Thorpe]]. During the 1912 [[Olympic Games|Olympics]] in Stockholm, Sweden, Thorpe won the gold medal in the [[Decathlon]] (among others). Thorpe notably also competed professionally in [[soccer]], [[baseball]], [[American Football]], and [[basketball]]; and competed collegiately in [[track and field]], [[soccer]], [[baseball]], [[lacrosse]], and did [[ballroom dancing]]. King [[Gustav V of Sweden]], while awarding Thorpe the decathlon gold said: "You, sir, are the greatest athlete in the world." That title has become associated with the decathlon event ever since.

{{distinguish|Bullfighting}} [[File:Bulls_Ishikawa,_Okinawa_2007.jpg|thumb|''Tōgyū'', or "Okinawan bullfighting", is a traditional sport of [[Japan]].]] '''Bull wrestling''', '''cow fighting''' or '''bull fighting''' is a non-lethal [[bloodsport]] between [[bull]]s or [[cow]]s found in some parts of the world.
==Balkans== [[File:Sanski Most Korida 2011 006.JPG|thumb|Korida in [[Sanski Most]], Bosnia and Herzegovina]] ''Korida'', from ''corrida'', or ''borbe bikova'' ("fights of bulls") is a traditional sport in [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] and [[Croatia]].
===Bosnia and Herzegovina=== [[Grmeč]], a mountain in the extreme west of [[Bosnia]], is the best-known site of bullfights in the [[Balkans]]. They are called the ''Korida of Grmeč'' (''Grmečka korida'') and have been organised on every first Sunday in August for over 200 years, attracting thousands of visitors. These are fights between bulls themselves and there is no death of a bull. Fights happen in an empty field.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://atlasobscura.com/place/bullfights-of-grmec |title=Bullfights of Grmec |work=Atlas Obscura |accessdate=16 February 2012}}</ref>
The korida of [[Grmeč]] was depicted by the sculptor [[Slobodan Pejić]]. The sculpture of two bulls in a fight, made in bronze in 2004, has been compared to a confrontation of the oppressor and the oppressed or of the Bosnian people and the [[Austrian Empire|Austrian Emperor]].<ref>{{sl icon}} Vanda Mušič (ed). Bassin, Aleksander. Kokot, Staša. ''Slobodan Pejić''. Self-published by Vanda Mušič Chapman. 2007. {{ISBN|978-961-245-325-1}}.</ref>
===Croatia=== In Croatia, koridas are traditionally organized in [[Dalmatian Hinterland]] region. <ref>{{cite web|last1=(www.dw.com)|first1=Deutsche Welle|title=Nepoznata atrakcija u Hrvatskoj: Borbe bikova {{!}} Panorama {{!}} DW {{!}} 26.07.2017|url=http://www.dw.com/bs/nepoznata-atrakcija-u-hrvatskoj-borbe-bikova/a-39837182|website=DW.COM|language=bs}}</ref>
==Turkey== Bull wrestling in Turkey is known as ''[[:tr:Boğa güreşi#T.C3.BCrkiye.27de bo.C4.9Fa g.C3.BCre.C5.9Fi|boğa güreşi]]'' (literally "bull wrestling"). Each year in the third week of June, the Kafkasör (Caucasus) festival takes place in the city of [[Artvin]]. At the beginning of the festival, certain rules are applied in order to save the bulls from injury. For example, if a bull retreats from the fight, it means defeat, etc.<ref name="Darke2011">{{cite book|author=Diana Darke|title=Eastern Turkey|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U9WwsQE6AJ4C&pg=PA334|accessdate=15 September 2013|year=2011|publisher=Bradt Travel Guides|isbn=978-1-84162-339-9|pages=334–}}</ref>
==East and Southeast Asia== [[File:Bullfighting in Yamakoshi, Nagaoka 2.webm|thumb|250px|thumbtime=0:03|Bull wrestling (''Ushi no tsunotsuki'') in [[Yamakoshi, Niigata|Yamakoshi]], [[Nagaoka, Niigata|Nagaoka City]], [[Niigata Prefecture]], [[Japan]]]] *''[[Tōgyū]]'', or "Okinawan bullfighting", is the traditional sport of the [[Ryukyu Islands]], in which two bulls attempt, as in [[sumo wrestling]], to push one another out of a ring.<ref name="University1999">{{cite book|author=Susan Sered Associate Professor in the Department of Sociology and Anthropology Bar-Ilan University|title=Women of the Sacred Groves : Divine Priestesses of Okinawa: Divine Priestesses of Okinawa|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T0wIW7d8G1sC&pg=PA119|accessdate=15 September 2013|date=12 February 1999|publisher=Oxford University Press, USA|isbn=978-0-19-535233-7|pages=119–}}</ref> *''Sossaum'' ({{lang-ko|소싸움}}) is a traditional sport of Korea, in which two oxen are pitted against each other.<ref>{{cite book|author=The National Folk Museum of Korea (South Korea)|title=Encyclopedia of Korean Seasonal Customs: Encyclopedia of Korean Folklore and Traditional Culture Vol. 1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xsR3BgAAQBAJ&pg=PA225|date=30 October 2014|publisher=길잡이미디어|isbn=978-89-92128-92-6|pages=225–}}</ref> *Bullfighting is also observed by the ethnic Hmong/Miao minority in China, Vietnam and Laos. Bulls are selected by age, horn length and size. They are enticed to fight usually after new year's or summer events. They are usually non-lethal events and bulls that carry the opposing bulls will get the most points if it is a draw. The loser is usually the bull that flees first even if winning.
==Western Asia== [[File:Oman bullfighting (5).jpg|thumb|right|Bullfighting in Oman]] In [[Oman]] and the [[United Arab Emirates]] two [[Brahman (cattle)|Brahman bull]]s are presented to each other and allowed to lock horns and fight, while their handlers hold ropes to separate them if necessary.<ref name="Darke2010">{{cite book|author=Diana Darke|title=Oman: The Bradt Travel Guide|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=J6QKSXYG5tYC&pg=PA29|accessdate=15 September 2013|year=2010|publisher=Bradt Travel Guides|isbn=978-1-84162-332-0|pages=29–}}</ref> The origins of bullfighting in Oman are unknown, though locals believe it was brought here by the [[Moors]] who had conquered Spain. Its existence in Oman and the UAE is also attributed to Portugal, which colonized the Omani coastline for nearly two centuries,<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.mangalorean.com/browsearticles.php?arttype=Feature&articleid=284# |title=Mangalorean.Com- Serving Mangaloreans Around The World!<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=2015-06-10 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111001233607/http://www.mangalorean.com/browsearticles.php?arttype=Feature&articleid=284# |archive-date=2011-10-01 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="AbedHellyer2001">{{cite book|author1=Ibrahim Abed|author2=Peter Hellyer|title=United Arab Emirates: A New Perspective|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QcMz3zV0qAMC&pg=PA72|accessdate=15 September 2013|year=2001|publisher=Trident Press Ltd|isbn=978-1-900724-47-0|pages=72–}}</ref> and also introduced bullfighting to Omani [[Zanzibar]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Africa Analysis: The Fortnightly Bulletin on Financial and Political Trends|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=k8C1AAAAIAAJ|accessdate=15 September 2013|year=2004|publisher=Africa Analysis|page=cxxxi}}</ref>
==South Asia== ''Dhiri'' or ''Dhirio'' ([[Konkani language|Konkani]]: धिरी,धिरयो) is a popular form of traditional bull wrestling in the state of [[Goa]], [[Coastal South West India]]. It was the weekend entertainment staple for most villages. Many families lived off the earnings made on appearance money and bets alone.<ref name=dhiri>{{cite news|last1=Kamat Maad|first1=Govind|title=Dhirio: Bullish about a banned fight|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/goa/Dhirio-Bullish-about-a-banned-fight/articleshow/3625723.cms|accessdate=26 April 2015|agency=TNN|publisher=The times of India|date=Oct 22, 2008}}</ref> The [[Panaji]] Bench of the high Court vide order dated 20.12.96 directed the State Government to take immediate steps to ban all types of animal fights including Dhiri organised in the State of Goa, which was finally banned in 1997.<ref name=panaji>{{cite book|last1=India. Parliament. House of the People|title=Lok Sabha Debates|date=1998|publisher=Lok Sabha Secretariat|page=152|accessdate=26 April 2015}}</ref> Dhiri bullfights are still very popular in Goa despite the ban. There have been demands for legalizing Dhiri.<ref name=heraldo>{{cite news|title=UGDP claims credit for legalising dhirios|url=http://www.heraldgoa.in/Goa/The-Sunday-Roundtable/ugdp-claims-credit-for-legalising-dhirios/25299.html|accessdate=26 April 2015|publisher=O Heraldo|date=26 Mar 2009}}</ref>
==Criticism== On 17 October 1987, during its 10th session, the [[Muslim World League|Islamic Council]] discussed the practices of bullfighting and animal pits (where two or more animals are agitated and forced to fight each other for the sole purpose of entertainment), and issued a [[fatwa]] that both are considered [[haraam]] (forbidden by Allah) due to their cruel nature.<ref>[http://www.binbaz.org.sa/mat/134 حكم الملاكمة ومصارعة الثيران والمصارعة الحرة |<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==See also== *[[Bull-baiting]] *[[Bullfighting]] *[[Camel wrestling]] *[[Alligator wrestling]] *[[Cockfight]] *[[Combat de Reines]], cow wrestling in Switzerland *[[Dog fighting]] *[[Horn fighting]], the way horned [[ungulate]]s fight

revision.comment: /* Typical activities in a circuit training */Typo
revision.text:
'''Circuit training''' is a form of body conditioning or [[endurance training]] or [[resistance training]] using high-intensity. It targets strength building or muscular endurance. An exercise "circuit" is one completion of all prescribed exercises in the program. When one circuit is complete, one begins the first exercise again for the next circuit. Traditionally, the time between exercises in circuit training is short, often with rapid movement to the next exercise.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sportireland.ie/Coaching-Ireland/Publications-/Circuit-Training.pdf|title=CIRCUIT TRAINING. Development of Strength & Conditioning|last=Comyns|first=Tom|date=|website=Coaching Ireland|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=19 July 2018}}</ref>
The program was developed by R.E. Morgan and G.T. Anderson in 1953 at the [[University of Leeds]] in [[England]].<ref name="UNM">{{cite web | url=http://www.unm.edu/~lkravitz/Article%20folder/circuits05.html | title=New Insights into Circuit Training| accessdate =2006-11-16| last=Kraviz| first=Len| work=| publisher=University of New Mexico| date=1996-01-01}}</ref>
==Typical activities in a circuit training== A circuit should work each section of the body individually. Typical activities include:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brianmac.co.uk/circuit.htm|title=Circuit Training|author=Brian Mackenzie|work=brianmac.co.uk}}</ref>
'''Upper-body''' *Push ups *Bench dips *Back extensions *Medicine ball chest pass *Bench lift *Inclined press up '''Core & trunk''' *Sit ups (lower abdominal) *Stomach crunch (upper abdominal) *Back extension chest raise '''Lower-body''' *Squat jumps *Compass jumps *Astride jumps *Step ups *Shuttle runs *Hopping shuttles *Bench squats '''Total-body''' *[[Burpee (exercise)|Burpees]] *Treadmills *Squat thrusts *Skipping *Jogging
==Effects of circuit training== Studies at Baylor University and The Cooper Institute show that circuit training is the most time efficient way to enhance cardiovascular fitness and muscle endurance. Studies show that circuit training helps women to achieve their goals and maintain them longer than other forms of exercise or diet.<ref name="Curves">Heavin, Gary and Colman, Carol, C. Reprint edition (December 7, 2004). ''Curves: Permanent Results Without Permanent Dieting'', {{ISBN|0-399-52956-X}}</ref>
Morgan and Anderson claim: {{quote| Perhaps a most profound finding of this study, from a health perspective, is that this investigation clearly shows that performance of this circuit of exercises,this level of intensity elicited oxygen consumption values (39% to 51.5% of VO2max) that meet established guidelines of the [[American College of Sports Medicine]] (ACSM) for the recommended intensity (40% to 85% of [[VO2max]]R) of exercise for developing and maintaining cardio-respiratory fitness.<ref>{{cite web|last=Klika|first=Brett|title=High-Intensity Circuit Training Using Body Weight: Maximum Results With Minimal Investment|url=http://journals.lww.com/acsm-healthfitness/Fulltext/2013/05000/HIGH_INTENSITY_CIRCUIT_TRAINING_USING_BODY_WEIGHT_.5.aspx#P98 |publisher=ACSM's Health & Fitness Journal|accessdate=20 September 2013|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Thus, this circuit not only provides a suitable muscular fitness stimulus but also helps to meet ACSM cardiovascular guidelines and the newly published Dietary Guidelines for Americans 2005 for physical activity.<ref name="UNM" /> }}
One advantage is that reduced station times will encourage the participants to lift heavier weights, which means they can achieve overload with smaller number of repetitions: typically in the range of 25 to 50 depending on their training goals.<ref name="ACSM">http://westvalley.edu/academics/pe_department/physical_education/programs/weighttraining/acsm-resistancetraining.pdf</ref>
==See also== * [[Bodyweight exercise]] * [[Threshold training]] * [[Calisthenics]] * [[General fitness training]] * [[High-intensity interval training]] * [[Interval training]] * [[Isometric exercise]] * [[Long slow distance]] *[[Power training]] * [[Plyometric]] * [[Endurance training|Resistance training]] * [[Stretching]] * [[Supercompensation]] * [[Weight training]] * [[vVO2max|vVO<sub>2</sub>max]]

''IDEA Today'', 14(1), 32–43. * {{Cite journal | title = American College of Sports Medicine Position Stand. The recommended quantity and quality of exercise for developing and maintaining cardiorespiratory and muscular fitness, and flexibility in healthy adults | journal = Medicine & Science in Sports & Exercise | volume = 30 | issue = 6 | pages = 975–991 | year = 1998 | pmid = 9624661 | doi=10.1097/00005768-199806000-00032 }} {{refend}}

[[File:Rick Pitino.jpg|right|thumb|[[Rick Pitino]], coach of the [[Louisville Cardinals men's basketball]] team, at the edge of the coach's box.]] The '''coach's box''' is a term used in numerous sports. In [[baseball]], it is the space where the [[first base coach]] and [[third base coach]] stands. It is also common practice for a coach who has a play at his base to leave the coach’s box to signal the player to slide, advance or return to a base. This may be allowed by the [[umpire (baseball)|umpire]] if the coach does not interfere with the play in any manner.[http://mlb.mlb.com/mlb/official_info/official_rules/start_end_4.jsp The Official Site of Major League Baseball: Official info: Official Rules] In [[basketball]], it's a line that represents how far a coach may come towards centercourt. In [[soccer]], the coach's box is simply a term for the typical area that the coach or manager is standing. ==See also== *[[Baseball field#Coach's boxes]] ==References== [[Category:Terminology used in multiple sports]] [[Category:Baseball terminology]] {{sport-stub}}

page.title: Concerns and controversies at the 2018 Asian Games

revision.text:
A number of concerns and controversies surfaced before and during the [[2018 Asian Games]] in [[Jakarta]] and [[Palembang]], [[Indonesia]].
==Prior to the Games==
Jakarta, consistently ranked as having one of the world's worst traffic congestion problems, is building a subway. However, it will not be ready until 2019, so organizers have proposed closing schools during the event to curb traffic from millions of commuting pupils. Authorities also proposed to set aside toll roads and bus lanes for special official and athlete use during the Games. Jakarta has also instated an [[Odd–even rationing|odd-even licence plate system]] to limit congestion.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-games-asia-indonesia/indonesia-confident-on-asian-games-preparations-traffic-concerns-remain-idUSKCN1GK1CC|title=Indonesia confident on Asian Games preparations, traffic concerns...|last=Davies|first=Ed|work=U.S.|access-date=21 July 2018|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.talkvietnam.org/2018/07/asian-games-2018-risks-of-traffic-jam-and-terror-attack-concern-organisers/|title=Asian Games 2018: Risks of traffic jam and terror attack concern organisers|date=18 July 2018|work=Talk Vietnam|access-date=21 July 2018|language=en-US}}</ref>
Air pollution also becomes a concern on both cities. Jakarta has long struggled to boost air quality, regularly rated as unsafe by the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) as Jakarta's average score on the Air Quality Index (AQI) had exceeded 100 during early July 2018, once reaching the "unhealthy" range at 171 on 11 AM, Tuesday, 17 July 2018. Palembang also had been constantly under risk of [[haze]] caused by peatland fire during dry season which coincides with the Games. Authorities are looking into the possibility of [[cloud seeding]] to combat the fire hotspots by triggering rainfall in dry areas with flares of salt shot into suitable clouds.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://in.reuters.com/article/us-games-asia-pollution/from-cloud-seeding-to-vehicle-curbs-indonesia-fights-pollution-ahead-of-asian-games-idINKBN1K713D|title=From cloud seeding to vehicle curbs, Indonesia fights pollution...|last=Editorial|first=Reuters|work=IN|access-date=21 July 2018|language=en-IN}}</ref> Authorities covered a polluted, foul-smelling river near the Asian Games athletes' village in Jakarta with black nylon mesh over fears it will be an eyesore at the showpiece event.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asia/jakarta-covers-up--stinky--toxic--river-near-asian-games-village-10549506|title=Jakarta covers up 'stinky, toxic' river near Asian Games village|work=Channel NewsAsia|access-date=21 July 2018|language=en-GB}}</ref>
Security is another concern, with the Games taking place just a few months after [[Surabaya bombings|a series of terror attacks]], which killed dozens of people and provoked fear over Islamist militants. Some 100,000 security staff including bomb squad and sniper teams will be deployed in Jakarta, Palembang, and West Java, where the majority of events are hosted. Local police said they have been taking part in a pre-Asian Games crackdown on terror suspects and petty street criminals.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://en.vietnamplus.vn/asian-games-2018-risks-of-traffic-jam-and-terror-attack-concern-organisers/134883.vnp|title=Asian Games 2018: Risks of traffic jam and terror attack concern organisers|date=18 July 2018|work=vietnamplus.vn|access-date=21 July 2018}}.</ref>
The Olympic Council of Malaysia (OCM) also raised concerns over [[Malaysia national football team|Malaysian men's U-16 national football team]] security issues due to the recent provocations by Indonesian fans at venues and on social media.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nst.com.my/sports/others/2018/08/396949/ocm-look-athletes-safety-asian-games|title=OCM look into athletes' safety at Asian Games|last=Peter|first=Fabian|work=New Straits Times|access-date=5 August 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> Although, it was initially triggered by the [[Instagram|Instagram's post]] of one Malaysian when they were competing the [[2018 AFF U-16 Youth Championship]] at [[East Java]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://jateng.tribunnews.com/2018/07/27/muda-muda-provokator-pemain-timnas-u-16-malaysia-pasang-terbalik-bendera-indonesia|title=Muda-muda Provokator, Pemain Timnas U-16 Malaysia Pasang Terbalik Bendera Indonesia - Tribun Jateng|date=2018-07-27|work=Tribun Jateng|access-date=2018-08-28|language=id-ID}}</ref>
On 21 July 2018, less than one month from the Games, women football venue of Gelora Sriwijaya Stadium in Palembang had been partially damaged in a riot during local football league. At least 335 seats had been destroyed by the mob.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://bola.kompas.com/read/2018/07/21/20005778/kecewa-dengan-manajemen-suporter-sriwijaya-fc-rusak-kursi-stadion|title=Kecewa dengan Manajemen, Suporter Sriwijaya FC Rusak Kursi Stadion - Kompas.com|last=Media|first=Kompas Cyber|date=21 July 2018|work=KOMPAS.com|access-date=21 July 2018|language=en}}</ref>
Officials had held Asian Games' men football tournament drawing three times due to protest from UAE and Palestine which were incidentally not included in the first drawing. Later, Iraq withdrew from tournament which forced officials to rebalance the groups by determining which of Palestine or UAE would be moved to Group C to replace Iraq.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.insidethegames.biz/articles/1068349/draw-for-asian-games-football-tournament-held-for-third-time|title=Draw for Asian Games football tournament held for third time|last=Mackay|first=Duncan|date=4 August 2018|work=insidethegames.biz|access-date=7 August 2018}}</ref>
Prior to the start of the [[Golf at the 2018 Asian Games|golf tournament of the Asian Games]], several national golf associations complained to the [[Court of Arbitration for Sport]] that Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, Macau and Uzbekistan had possibly entered professional golfers, but the CAS ruled that none of the players were professional as the golf tournament was reserved only for the amateur players.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://uk.reuters.com/article/games-asia-golf/games-cas-satisfied-asian-games-golfers-arent-professional-idUKL8N1VD3CD|title=Games-CAS satisfied Asian Games golfers aren't professional |agency=Reuters|date=24 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Careem|first=Nazvi|date=23 August 2018|title=Asian Games: pros cut from Sri Lanka golf squad after Hong Kong and others complain about breach of amateur rules|url=https://www.scmp.com/sport/golf/article/2160924/asian-games-pros-cut-sri-lanka-golf-squad-after-hong-kong-and-others|work=[[South China Morning Post]]|location=Hong Kong, China|access-date=24 August 2018}}</ref>
==During the Games==
===Alcohol ban=== The Indonesian Asian Games Organizing Committee ([[Indonesian Olympic Committee|INASGOC]]) banned athletes competing in the Games from consuming alcohol and outside food in their accommodation in the host cities of Jakarta and Palembang. On 28 August 2018, officials said they had confiscated many bottles and cans of beer that athletes and officials had tried to bring in from outside the athletes' villages.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Potkin |first1=Fanny |title=No Drowning Your Sorrows: Indonesia Bans Alcohol at Athletes' Villages |url=http://jakartaglobe.id/news/no-drowning-sorrows-indonesia-bans-alcohol-athletes-villages/ |accessdate=30 August 2018 |agency=Reuters |publisher=Jakarta Globe |date=28 August 2018}}</ref>
===Alleged gratification===
Since the sales of closing ceremony ticket, Indonesian anti-corruption commission, [[Corruption Eradication Commission|KPK]] has alleged to receive 14 free tickets with 13 of them had not been used. The gratification allegations started when the state enterprises of Indonesia ([[State-owned Enterprise of Indonesia|BUMN]]) bought several tickets, KPK has warned some officials in BUMN to report back of the buying. [[Jusuf Kalla]], Vice President of Indonesia, had declared that "it did not include in gratification because it is less than Rp 10 millions [threshold of official gratification in Indonesia]". Even more, KPK had not known whether it was included in gratifications or not.<ref>{{cite news|last=Dewi|first=Santi|title=KPK Terima 14 Laporan Dugaan Gratifikasi Tiket Asian Games 2018|url=https://www.idntimes.com/news/indonesia/santi-dewi/kpk-sudah-terima-14-laporan-penerimaan-tiket-asian-games|work=IDN TIMES|date=5 September 2018|accessdate=5 September 2018|language=id}}</ref>
===Organizational issues===
During the medal ceremony of [[Swimming at the 2018 Asian Games – Men's 200 metre freestyle|men's 200 metre freestyle]] swimming on 19 August 2018, the flags of the three medalists crashed to the ground due to a technical malfunction. [[Sun Yang]], the Chinese swimmer and the gold medalist of the event, immediately got off the podium, walked to some officials and demanded the medal ceremony to be conducted once again. The flags were re-attached to the broken hoist but couldn't be raised, and the [[March of the Volunteers|Chinese anthem]] was played for a second time.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/sun-celebrates-asian-games-win-upset-over-flag-malfunction/2018/08/19/29fa97cc-a3bc-11e8-ad6f-080770dcddc2_story.html|title=Sun celebrates Asian Games gold medal before flags fall|last=Pye|first=John|date=19 August 2018|work=The Washington Post|access-date=20 August 2018}}</ref>
===Athletics===
On 25 August 2018, [[Hiroto Inoue]] won the Asian Games men's marathon in a controversial sprint finish, with Bahrain later lodging a complaint to race officials, accusing the Japanese runner of barging second-place finisher [[Elhassan Elabbassi]].<ref>{{cite news| url = https://mobile.reuters.com/article/amp/idUSKCN1LA04M| title = Asian Games: Bahrain complain after Inoue wins marathon for Japan | author = Amlan Chakraborty | date = August 25, 2018 | accessdate = August 26, 2018}}</ref> Meanwhile, on the same day, a [[cat]] [[pitch invasion|ran into the track]] of the Gelora Bung Karno Main Stadium during the interval of women's 100m qualification competition.<ref>{{cite news| url = http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-08/26/c_137419050_3.htm| title = Cat runs into track during 18th Asian Games in Jakarta, Indonesia | author = Xinhua | date = August 25, 2018 | accessdate = August 26, 2018}}</ref>
===Basketball===
Coach [[Yeng Guiao]] of the [[Philippines men's national basketball team|Philippine men's National Basketball team]] raised doubts on why a Hong Kong referee officiated the match up between China and the Philippines. Despite having its own organized sports body, [[Hong Kong]] is special administrative region of the of China. He questioned the number of China's free throw attempts to the Philippines', 39 foul shots to 15. The Chinese team was assessed to only 16 fouls compared to the Philippines, 25.<ref>{{cite news| url = https://www.philstar.com/sports/2018/08/23/1845139/no-excuses-yeng-guiao-calls-out-hong-kong-referee#L99T6ZcO1ydb21Xv.99 | title = No excuses but Yeng Guiao calls out Hong Kong referee | author = Joaquin Henson | date = August 23, 2018 | accessdate = August 24, 2018}}</ref>
===Boxing=== In women's 57 kg, Filipino boxer Nesthy Petecio lost a controversial bout against Chinese rival Yin Junhua to the surprise of most of the crowd at the Jakarta International Expo Hall C. Japanese and Turkmen judges ruled in favor of the Filipino while Bulgarian and South Korean judges ruled in favor of the Chinese. The French judge scored a 28-28, but later handed the fight to the Chinese to break the deadlock. Petecio shed tears of anger and stared at the judges. Philippine chef de mission [[Richard Gomez]] said it's a case of “bad call, bad decision and bad scoring” while [[Association of Boxing Alliances in the Philippines]] (ABAP) executive director Ed Picson blasted the result of the bout and appeals to officials “that the judges responsible for this travesty not be assigned to officiate in the coming Philippines fights as judges or referees.”<ref>{{cite news| url = https://www.philstar.com/sports/2018/08/25/1845769/petecio-phl-sports-officials-cry-foul | title = Petecio, Phl sports officials cry foul | author = Nelson Beltran | date = August 25, 2018 | accessdate = August 28, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://manilastandard.net/sports/fightsports/273907/boxing-exec-wants-3-judges-banned-from-philippine-asiad-fights.html|title= Boxing exec wants 3 judges banned from Philippine Asiad fights |date=25 August 2018|work=Manila Standard|access-date=28 August 2018}}</ref>
===Football===
[[Luis Milla]], the head coach of [[Indonesia national under-23 football team|Indonesian men's national football team]] called the referee Shaun Evans from Australia 'unfit' after he gave two controversial penalties during a game between Indonesia and the United Arab Emirates. Milla was disappointed because the referee was biased during the whole game. "The referee doesn't have any competence to officiate at the Asian Games. He [Shaun Evans] is not on that level. He's the [opponent’s] 12th player and I am sad that our players' struggle had to end like this," the Spanish coach said. The Indonesian goalkeeper, [[Andritany Ardhiyasa]], added at the press conference, "Today is a sad day for us because we were robbed by [the referee]. The second penalty should not have been awarded".<ref>{{cite news| url = http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2018/08/24/asian-games-uae-eliminates-indonesia-in-round-of-16-soccer-match.html | title = Asian Games: UAE eliminates Indonesia in round of 16 soccer match | author = Fachrul Sidiq | date = August 24, 2018 | accessdate = August 20, 2018}}</ref>
===Pencak Silat===
On 26 August 2018, in the Semifinal of [[Pencak silat at the 2018 Asian Games – Men's tanding 90 kg|Men's tanding 85 kg to 90 kg]], Muhammad Robial Sobri, a Malaysian athlete, deliberately kicked his Singaporean opponent, Sheik Alauddin Sheik Ferdous, after the Singaporean had fell to the ground.<ref>{{cite news| url = http://theindependent.sg/malaysian-silat-athlete-sparks-uproar-after-illegally-kicking-singaporean-opponent-while-hes-down/| title = Malaysian silat athlete sparks uproar after illegally kicking Singaporean opponent while he’s down | author = Jewel Stolarchuk | date = August 28, 2018 | accessdate = August 28, 2018}}</ref>
On 27 August 2018, another Malaysian pencak silat athlete, Mohd Al-Jufferi Jamari accused the judges of bias. Even he was walked out off the [[Pencak silat at the 2018 Asian Games – Men's tanding 70 kg|final match]], the furious three-time world champion left a damage in the changing room's partition at venue after the match,<ref>{{cite news| url = https://www.nst.com.my/sports/others/2018/08/405445/malaysia-robbed-silat-gold| title = Malaysia robbed of silat gold | work = New Straits Times | date = August 27, 2018 | accessdate = August 28, 2018}}</ref> something for which the Malaysian delegation had apologized.<ref>{{cite news| url = https://www.cnnindonesia.com/olahraga/20180829214728-178-326029/sekjen-pencak-silat-malaysia-minta-maaf-atas-aksi-al-jufferi| title = Sekjen Pencak Silat Malaysia Minta Maaf Atas Aksi Al Jufferi | work = CNN Indonesia | date = August 29, 2018 | accessdate = September 4, 2018| language=id}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url = https://www.scmp.com/sport/other-sport/article/2161932/asian-games-indonesia-little-things-they-declare-war-malaysia| title = Asian Games: ‘Indonesia is like that, little things they declare war’ – Malaysia fuming over pencak silat ‘walk-off’ incident | work = South China Morning Post | date = August 30, 2018 | accessdate = September 1, 2018}}</ref> Indonesia had won 14 out of 16 gold medals on offer, while several countries including Singapore and Iran had complain about the judging in this event, claiming that judges are favouring local atheltes.<ref name="silat">{{cite news| url = https://www.scmp.com/sport/other-sport/article/2162113/asian-games-indonesia-rejects-pencak-silat-cheating-claims-says#comments| title = Asian Games: Indonesia rejects pencak silat cheating claims – top official Erick Thohir ‘saddened by fellow Muslim countries’ | work = South China Moring Post | date = August 31, 2018 | accessdate = September 1, 2018}}</ref>
On the other hand, the Indonesian Asian Games Organizing Committee (INASGOC) chairman [[Erick Thohir]], had rejected accusations of cheating, claiming that the game "is open, with people can see it on television and it is clear". Erick also insisted that they have "monitor closely all judges, who are chosen by the Asian governing body".<ref name="silat"/> He added that, "We see the domination of certain countries in sports such as judo, karate and taekwondo. The funny thing is when Indonesia achieves such success, why do people complain?".<ref name="silat" />
==Doping==
On August 24, Turkmenistani wrestler, Rustem Nazarov became the first athlete to fail a doping test. Nazarov had competed in the men's 57 kilograms freestyle event on August 19 and was beaten 12-8 in his first match by India's Sandeep Tomar.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.manilastandard.net/sports/sports-plus/273855/doping-case-hits-asiad-ikee-eyes-history.html|title= Doping case hits Asiad, Ikee eyes history |date=24 August 2018|work=Manila Standard|access-date=13 September 2018}}</ref>
On September 2, Mongolian reigning world champion Orkhon Purevdorj was stripped of the gold medal she claimed in the women's 62 kilogram event. Purevdorj tested positive for anabolic steroid [[Stanazolol]] and received lengthy ban on sporting events.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://vietnamnews.vn/sports/465322/mongolia-loses-wrestling-gold-promoting-viet-nams-ranking-in-asiad.html|title= Mongolia loses wrestling gold, promoting Việt Nam’s ranking in ASIAD |date=7 September 2018|work=Việt Nam News|access-date=13 September 2018}}</ref>

{{History of American football}} [[Concussion]]s and other types of repetitive play-related head blows in [[American football]] have been shown to be the cause of [[chronic traumatic encephalopathy]] (CTE), which has led to player deaths and other debilitating symptoms after retirement, including memory loss, [[depression (mood)|depression]], anxiety, headaches, and also sleep disturbances.<ref>{{Cite book|title=concussions|last=Meehan III|first=William|publisher=|year=2017|isbn=9781440838941|location=Santa Barbara, California|pages=}}</ref>
The [[List of NFL players with chronic traumatic encephalopathy|list of ex-NFL players]] that have either been diagnosed ''post-mortem'' with [[Chronic traumatic encephalopathy|CTE]] or have reported symptoms of CTE continues to grow.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.kansascity.com/sports/nfl/article58501703.html|title=The grim list of football players with CTE continues to grow|work=kansascity|access-date=2017-04-05|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/02/04/sports/football/ken-stabler-nfl-cte-brain-disease.html?nytmobile=0|title=Ken Stabler, a Magnetic NFL Star, Was Sapped of Spirit by C.T.E.|last=Branch|first=John|access-date=2017-04-05}}</ref>
According to the Boston University CTE Center, CTE is a brain degenerative disease found in athletes, military veterans, and others with history of repetitive brain trauma. Although CTE is highly controversial and misunderstood; it is believed that a protein called Tau forms clumps that slowly spread throughout the brain, killing brain cells.
==Concussions in the National Football League== {{see also|list of NFL players with post-concussion syndrome}}
=== History === A [[concussion]], from the Latin word [[wiktionary:concussio|''concussio'']], is a frequent injury among football players. Concussions occur when the head is subject to a large impact force, resulting in a minor brain injury. There has been a growing concern about concussions since the early 1900s. In 1906, a Harvard student athlete died from a head injury and the team doctors released a report titled "The Physical Aspect of American Football" in the Boston Medical and Surgical Journal describing the type, severity, and number of injuries the team sustained in the 1905 season.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Harrison|first1=Emily|title=The First Concussion Crisis; Head Injury and Evidence in Early American Football|journal=Public Health Then and Now|date=May 2014|volume=104|issue=5|page=825}}</ref>
The NFL first began to review the subject formally in 1994, then [[NFL Commissioner]] [[Paul Tagliabue]] approved the creation of the Mild Traumatic Brain Injury (MTBI) Committee with the stated goal of studying the effects of concussions and sub-concussive injury in NFL players. Tagliabue appointed [[rheumatologist]] Elliot Pellman to chair the committee.<ref name="Peter">{{cite web|last=Peter|first=Peter|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espnmag/story?id=3644940|title=Elliot Pellman, the NFL's top medical adviser, claims it's okay for players with concussions to get back in the game. Time for a second choice|publisher=ESPN Sports|accessdate=2013-09-03}}</ref> Pellman's appointment was met with harsh criticism, because he is not a neurologist or [[neuropsychologist]] and often admitted ignorance about head injuries.<ref name="Peter"/> The concussion data collected by the league from 1996 to 2001 has been shown to understate the actual number of diagnosed concussions by ten percent. The league legal representation has been shown to have had ties to the tobacco industry legal defense.<ref>Alan Schwarz, Walt Bogdanich and Jacqueline Williams. (24 March 2016). "In NFL, Deeply Flawed Concussion Research and Ties to Big Tobacco " The New York Times. (New York). Retrieved 24 March 2016. [http://www.msn.com/en-us/sports/nfl/in-nfl-deeply-flawed-concussion-research-and-ties-to-big-tobacco/ar-BBqRt5G?ocid=spartandhp MSN website]</ref> {{Importance inline}}
The same year, the [[National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health]] (NIOSH) reported a statistically significant increase in the risk of [[neurological]] disorders such as [[amyotrophic lateral sclerosis]] (ALS) in retired football players, which furthered public knowledge about the risk of long-term neurocognitive disease related to repeated head impacts.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/hhe/reports/pdfs/1988-0085-letter.pdf|title=Concussion in professional football: helmet testing to assess impact performance – part 11|publisher=[[United States Public Health Service]] [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] [[National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health]]|date=2004-01-10|accessdate=2013-09-03}}</ref> Despite the NIOSH study, Pellman and the MTBI Committee drew their own conclusions that continued to contradict these findings and those of other organizations. Biomechanical engineers and neurosurgeons informed the Committee that the helmet safety standard at that time was insufficient to minimize the risk of concussions.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Concussion in professional football: helmet testing to assess impact performance – part 11|date=January 2006|pmid=16385332|volume=58|vauthors=Pellman EJ, Viano DC, Withnall C, Shewchenko N, Bir CA, Halstead PD |pages=78–96; discussion 78–96|journal=Neurosurgery|doi=10.1227/01.neu.0000196265.35238.7c}}</ref>
The MTBI Committee began studying the nature of [[Tackle (American football)|tackle]] plays resulting in concussive impacts and developing its own biomechanical analysis of the effect of these forces on the brain.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Practice parameter: the management of concussion in sports (summary statement). Report of the Quality Standards Subcommittee.|journal=Neurology|date=March 1997|volume=48|issue=3|pages=581–5|doi=10.1212/WNL.48.3.581|pmid=9065530}}</ref> It started publishing study results in 2003 that stated there were no long-term negative health consequences associated with concussions sustained by NFL players. A six-year study by the Committee concluded that, "Players who are concussed and return to the same game have fewer initial signs and symptoms than those removed from play. Return to play does not involve a significant risk of a second injury either in the same game or during the season."<ref>{{cite journal|title=Concussion in professional football: players returning to the same game – part 7 |pmid=15617589 | volume=56|vauthors=Pellman EJ, Viano DC, Casson IR, Arfken C, Feuer H |pages=79–90; discussion 90–92|journal=Neurosurgery|doi=10.1227/01.neu.0000150180.16552.8d}}</ref>
=== Research === Other organizations continued to publish study results that linked repeated concussions and long-term health problems contrary to reports by the MTBI Committee. A 2003 report by the Center for the Study of Retired Athletes at the [[University of North Carolina]], for example, found a connection between numerous concussions and depression among former professional football players. Further, the Center's follow-up study in 2005 associated both brain impairment and Alzheimer's disease with retired NFL players who had histories of concussions.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Association between recurrent concussion and late-life cognitive impairment in retired professional football players. |pmid=16239884 | volume=57|date=Oct 2005|pages=719–26|journal=Neurosurgery|doi=10.1227/01.NEU.0000175725.75780.DD}}</ref>
A 2004 doctoral dissertation by Don Brady examined NFL Players' knowledge of concussions, studying both active and retired National Football League Players' knowledge of concussions. Brady's findings concluded: that many NFL players lacked accurate and essential knowledge pertaining to various aspects of a concussion; that the preponderance of credible experimental and clinical evidence pertaining to the adverse effects of concussion indicates that the brain is injured as a result of a concussion; that the altered cell functioning and cell death along with subtle to more visible neurological, neurocognitive, psychological, and other medical problems reflect a diverse range of lifelong negative consequences of a concussion / brain injury; and that sports team health-care personnel need to focus primarily on the athletes' health and well-being, and not minimize an injury or primarily concentrate on the players' capacity to perform on the field. This expanded focus of health care is necessary in order to avoid any real or perceived conflicts of interest emerging in the concussion research, concussion management and related return to play decision-making process.<ref name=Brady04>{{cite thesis |type=Ph.D. |first=Don |last=Brady |title=A Preliminary Investigation of Active and Retired NFL Players' Knowledge of Concussions |publisher=The Union Institute and University |year=2004}}</ref>
During November 2014, Brady filed objections to the proposed NFL concussion settlement offer.
